Column Comment.0: CONTRACT ID: Unique identifier for the contract table.
Column Comment.1: OPERATING PROCEDURE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for the operatingprocedure.
Column Comment.2: SUBSTANCE IDENTIFIER: Unique identifier for a substance that can be describedeither chemically or in terms of composition. Elements, ions, isotopes, isomers,minerals, chemicals, solvents, production substances, hydrocarbons etc are all listed.Be advised that many applications and agencies may use the same term, but thedefinition and composition details may not be the same. Use the SUBSTANCE XREFtable to capture relationships between substances, such as similar substances.
Column Comment.3: SUBSTANCE OBSERVATION NUMBER: A unique number allowing a substance tobe a marketing election substance off and on throughout the lifetime of the contract.Use the ACTIVE IND to determine which rows of data are currently valid.
Column Comment.4: ACTIVE INDICATOR: A Y/N flag indicating whether this row of data is currently eitheractive / valid (Y) or inactive / invalid (N).
Column Comment.5: BOTH INDICATOR: A yes / no flag indicating whether the election cost and theelection percent must be added to obtain the complete sum for the election. If set toY, they must be added. If set to N, only the populated column is relevant.
Column Comment.6: EFFECTIVE DATE: The date that an associated substance(s) was valid to bemarketed by the operator on behalf of the joint account.
Column Comment.7: ELECTION COST: an amount or fee associated with a specified business associateelection (e.g. marketing fee is equal to a specified flat fee of M3 production of naturalgas liquids - CAPL 1990 Operating Procedure)
Column Comment.8: ELECTION COST QUALIFIER: a restriction on the amount to be charged formarketing substances on behalf of a business associate by the operator. (e.g. not toexceed, etc.)
Column Comment.9: ELECTION PERCENT: a percentage marketing fee to be charged by the operator onall production produced on behalf of a business associate not taking producedsubstance in kind.
Column Comment.10: ELECTION PERCENT QUALIFIER: a restriction on the percentage of the marketingfee to be charged on produced substance(s) by the operator. (e.g. not to exceed,etc.)
Column Comment.11: EXPIRY DATE: the date on which this row of data is no longer in effect from abusiness perspective.
Column Comment.12: ROW_MANAGEMENT_GUID: This value may be used to provide a global uniqueidentifier for this row of data. Use of this column is not mandatory, but if used,optional PPDM NOT NULL and UNIQUE INDEX constraints provided in the datamodel DDL should be created.
Column Comment.13: REMARK: Narrative remarks about this row of data.
Column Comment.14: SOURCE: The individual, company, state, or government agency designated as thesource of information for this row.
Column Comment.15: SUBSTANCE ORIGINAL UNITS OF MEASURE: the original units of measuredeclared for the substance in the contract. (e.g. contract may state bbls.)
Column Comment.16: SUBSTANCE UOM: The current units of measure for a specified substance that isbeing used in the conduct of business. (not indicated in contract)
Column Comment.17: ROW CHANGED BY: Application login id of the user who last changed the row.
Column Comment.18: ROW CHANGED DATE: System date of the last time the row was changed.
Column Comment.19: ROW CREATED BY: System user who created this row of data.
Column Comment.20: ROW CREATED DATE: Date that the row was created on.
Column Comment.21: ROW_EFFECTIVE_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of datais effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row of data wasmade available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.22: ROW_EXPIRY_DATE: A system assigned date that specified when a row of data isno longer effective from a systems perspective. This may be the date that a row ofdata was no longer available to end users, for example.
Column Comment.23: PPDM ROW QUALITY: A set of values indicating the quality of data in this row,usually with reference to the method or procedures used to load the data, althoughother types of quality reference are permitted.
